item.title: Comment on Gender Composition and Group Behavior by Tyler
item.description:
The world seems to be settling on the very reasonable and non-extreme conclusion that a critical mass of any demographic group is useful to ensuring that other typical members of that group feel comfortable being a part of that team/company/etc. But (at least for gender) that critical mass is notably lower than 50%. So we don't need parity, we just need critical mass (e.g. enough male kindergarten teachers to let other men considering that job to feel a bit more comfortable). Each organization will have to decide whether the costs of maintaining that critical mass (potentially weighing the scales for candidates based on gender, for example, lowering overall quality) outweigh the benefits (retaining attractiveness to a wider group of candidates at all times).

item.title: Comment on Health insurance companies are not the main villain by Doc Brown
item.description:
People’s complaint about United Healthcare in particular is their care decisions seem arbitrary. Being bureaucratically inconsistent as a way to ration care loses trust and makes enemies.

As an example I have a friend with a congenital issue in their knees. UHC approved the surgery on his left knee last year; they then decided they could pay for part of the surgery on the right knee this year. He’s angry at them, but he’d be less angry if they’d given a consistent no. And maybe if he’d done a ton of work to fight it, he could have gotten it approved.

And of course that you don’t know what you’ll pay in American Healthcare until long after you get the care is unpopular and evidence of market dysfunction.

item.title: Comment on The New Jersey drone sightings by Silvanus
item.description:
No, you can't really trust the mayor of Belleville on this lol. Almost all the videos I've seen have been planes, very obviously so.

I think this is mostly public hysteria by people not used to looking up at the night sky. Likely a few weeks back either a small DOD test or a few amateurs having some fun and flying drones around at night. Then rumors spread and everyone is looking up, claiming everything is a drone. These things then get in people's heads and they run with it, claiming there's no way they could be mistaken, etc.

By the way, this kind of thing has happened in the exact same place before: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morristown_UFO_hoax
